procedure.title: Working Machine Fire Safety: Maintenance and Emergency Response
procedure.goal: To prevent working machine fires through regular maintenance and to provide clear steps for responding to a fire emergency.

steps.note: Section: Routine Maintenance. Prevents ignition and improves cooling.
Check hoses, pipes, and joints. Repair any leaks immediately.

steps.action: perform annual inspection of electrical systems
steps.note: Check for voltage drops, anomalies, and damage. Document inspections.
Ensure components are secure, clean, and have terminal covers.
Check for leaks and ensure all heat shields are in place.

steps.action: inspect and service first-aid extinguishing equipment
steps.note: Ensure equipment is available, marked, and serviced annually.
Section: Special Operations. Check cleanliness, wiring, and exhaust.
This is a high-temperature combustion process requiring supervision.

conditions: in case of fire, if machine is indoors or near flammable material
steps.note: Section: Emergency Engine Fire Response. This step must precede engine shutdown.
Do not assume the fire is out, even if it appears controlled.

constraints.text: Clean daily in dusty or fire-hazard conditions; otherwise, clean at least weekly.
Always use authentic replacement parts from known manufacturers.
Shut down the engine before inspecting for fuel leaks.
Cables in the engine compartment must have fastening brackets no more than 150 mm apart.
Machines in hazardous environments (e.g., timber, peat) must have a fixed, automatic fire extinguishing system.
Operators must be trained in the use of fire extinguishers.
Ensure regeneration occurs in a safe outdoor environment away from flammable materials.
Never leave the machine unattended during regeneration.
If a fire occurs in a hazardous location, move the machine *before* shutting down the engine.
